verses.text: The several heads of error which were alleged against Pelagius at the Synod in Palestine, with his answers to each charge, are minutely discussed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:62
verses.text: Augustin shows that, although Pelagius was acquitted by the synod, there still clave to him the suspicion of heresy; and that the acquittal of the accused by the synod was so contrived, that the heresy itself with which he was charged was unhesitatingly condemned.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:63
verses.text: Chapter 1.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:64
verses.text: —Introduction.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:65
verses.text: After there came into my hands, holy father Aurelius, the ecclesiastical proceedings, by which fourteen bishops of the province of Palestine pronounced Pelagius a catholic, my hesitation, in which I was previously reluctant to make any lengthy or confident statement about the defence which he had made, came to an end.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:66
verses.text: This defence, indeed, I had already read in a paper which he himself forwarded to me.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:67
verses.text: Forasmuch, however, as I received no letter therewith from him, I was afraid that some discrepancy might be detected between my statement and the record of the ecclesiastical proceedings; and that, should Pelagius perhaps deny that he had sent me any paper (and it would have been difficult for me to prove that he had, when there was only one witness), I should rather seem guilty in the eyes of those who would readily credit his denial, either of an underhanded falsification, or else (to say the least) of a reckless credulity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 1:68
verses.text: Now, however, when I am to treat of matters which are shown to have actually transpired, and when, as it appears to me, all doubt is removed whether he really acted in the way described, your holiness, and everybody who reads these pages, will no doubt be able to judge, with greater readiness and certainty, both of his defence and of this my treatment of it.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2 (I.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:2
verses.text: )—The First Item in the Accusation, and Pelagius' Answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:3
verses.text: First of all, then, I offer to the Lord my God, who is also my defence and guide, unspeakable thanks, because I was not misled in my views respecting our holy brethren and fellow-bishops who sat as judges in that case.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:4
verses.text: His answers, indeed, they not without reason approved; because they had not to consider how he had in his writings stated the points which were objected against him, but what he had to say about them in his reply at the pending examination.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:5
verses.text: A case of unsoundness in the faith is one thing, one of incautious statement is another thing.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:6
verses.text: Now sundry objections were urged against Pelagius out of a written complaint, which our holy brethren and fellow-bishops in Gaul, Heros and Lazarus, presented, being themselves unable to be present, owing (as we afterwards learned from credible information) to the severe indisposition of one of them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:7
verses.text: The first of these was, that he writes, in a certain book of his, this: "No man can be without sin unless he has acquired a knowledge of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:8
verses.text: After this had been read out, the synod inquired: "Did you, Pelagius, express yourself thus?" Then in answer he said: "I certainly used the words, but not in the sense in which they understand them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:9
verses.text: I did not say that a man is unable to sin who has acquired a knowledge of the law; but that he is by the knowledge of the law assisted towards not sinning, even as it is written, 'He hath given them a law for help'"  Upon hearing this, the synod declared: "The words which have been spoken by Pelagius are not different from the Church".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:10
verses.text: Assuredly they are not different, as he expressed them in his answer; the statement, however, which was produced from his book has a different meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:11
verses.text: But this the bishops, who were Greek-speaking men, and who heard the words through an interpreter, were not concerned with discussing.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 2:12
verses.text: All they had to consider at the moment was, what the man who was under examination said was his meaning,—not in what words his opinion was alleged to have been expressed in his book.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:2
verses.text: —Discussion of Pelagius' First Answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:3
verses.text: Now to say that "a man is by the knowledge of the law assisted towards not sinning," is a different assertion from saying that "a man cannot be without sin unless he has acquired a knowledge of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:4
verses.text: We see, for example, that corn-floors may be threshed without threshing-sledges,—however much these may assist the operation if we have them; and that boys can find their way to school without the pedagogue,—however valuable for this may be the office of pedagogues; and that many persons recover from sickness without physicians,—although the doctor's skill is clearly of greatest use; and that men sometimes live on other aliments besides bread,—however valuable the use of bread must needs be allowed to be; and many other illustrations may occur to the thoughtful reader, without our prompting.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:5
verses.text: From which examples we are undoubtedly reminded that there are two sorts of aids.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:6
verses.text: Some are indispensable, and without their help the desired result could not be attained.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:7
verses.text: Without a ship, for instance, no man could take a voyage; no man could speak without a voice; without legs no man could walk; without light nobody could see; and so on in numberless instances.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:8
verses.text: Amongst them this also may be reckoned, that without God's grace no man can live rightly.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:9
verses.text: But then, again, there are other helps, which render us assistance in such a way that we might in some other way effect the object to which they are ordinarily auxiliary in their absence.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:10
verses.text: Such are those which I have already mentioned,—the threshing-sledges for threshing corn, the pedagogue for conducting the child, medical art applied to the recovery of health, and other like instances.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:11
verses.text: We have therefore to inquire to which of these two classes belongs the knowledge of the law,—in other words, to consider in what way it helps us towards the avoidance of sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:12
verses.text: If it be in the sense of indispensable aid without which the end cannot be attained; not only was Pelagius' answer before the judges true, but what he wrote in his book was true also.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:13
verses.text: If, however, it be of such a character that it helps indeed if it is present, but even if it be absent, then the result is still possible to be attained by some other means,—his answer to the judges was still true, and not unreasonably did it find favour with the bishops that "man is assisted not to sin by the knowledge of the law;" but what he wrote in his book is not true, that "there is no man without sin except him who has acquired a knowledge of the law,"—a statement which the judges left undiscussed, as they were ignorant of the Latin language, and were content with the confession of the man who was pleading his cause before them, especially as no one was present on the other side who could oblige the interpreter to expose his meaning by an explanation of the words of his book, and to show why it was that the brethren were not groundlessly disturbed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:14
verses.text: For but very few persons are thoroughly acquainted with the law.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:15
verses.text: The mass of the members of Christ, who are scattered abroad everywhere, being ignorant of the very profound and complicated contents of the law, are commended by the piety of simple faith and unfailing hope in God, and sincere love.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 3:16
verses.text: Endowed with such gifts, they trust that by the grace of God they may be purged from their sins through our Lord Jesus Christ.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4 (II.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:2
verses.text: )—The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:3
verses.text: If Pelagius, as he possibly might, were to say in reply to this, that that very thing was what he meant by "the knowledge of the law, without which a man is unable to be free from sins," which is communicated by the teaching of faith to converts and to babes in Christ, and in which candidates for baptism are catechetically instructed with a view to their knowing the creed, certainly this is not what is usually meant when any one is said to have a knowledge of the law.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:4
verses.text: This phrase is only applied to such persons as are skilled in the law.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:5
verses.text: But if he persists in describing the knowledge of the law by the words in question, which, however few in number, are great in weight, and are used to designate all who are faithfully baptized according to the prescribed rule of the Churches; and if he maintains that it was of this that he said, "No one is without sin, but the man who has acquired the knowledge of the law,"—a knowledge which must needs be conveyed to believers before they attain to the actual remission of sins,—even in such case there would crowd around him a countless multitude, not indeed of angry disputants, but of crying baptized infants, who would exclaim,—not, to be sure, in words, but in the very truthfulness of innocence,—"What is it, O what is it that you have written: 'He only can be without sin who has acquired a knowledge of the law?' See here are we, a large flock of lambs, without sin, and yet we have no knowledge of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:6
verses.text: Now surely they with their silent tongue would compel him to silence, or, perhaps, even to confess that he was corrected of his great perverseness; or else (if you will), that he had already for some time entertained the opinion which he acknowledged before his ecclesiastical examiners, but that he had failed before to express his opinion in words of sufficient care,—that his faith, therefore, should be approved, but this book revised and amended.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:7
verses.text: For, as the Scripture says: "There is that slippeth in his speech, but not in his heart".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:8
verses.text: Now if he would only admit this, or were already saying it, who would not most readily forgive those words which he had committed to writing with too great heedlessness and neglect, especially on his declining to defend the opinion which the said words contain, and affirming that to be his proper view which the truth approves? This we must suppose would have been in the minds of the pious judges themselves, if they could only have duly understood the contents of his Latin book, thoroughly interpreted to them, as they understood his reply to the synod, which was spoken in Greek, and therefore quite intelligible to them, and adjudged it as not alien from the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 4:9
verses.text: Let us go on to consider the other cases.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5 (III.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:2
verses.text: )—The Second Item in the Accusation; And Pelagius' Answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:3
verses.text: The synod of bishops then proceeded to say: "Let another section be read".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:4
verses.text: Accordingly there was read the passage in the same book wherein Pelagius had laid down the position that "all men are ruled by their own will".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:5
verses.text: On this being read, Pelagius said in answer: "This I stated in the interest of free will.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:6
verses.text: God is its helper whenever it chooses good; man, however, when sinning is himself in fault, as under the direction of a free will".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:7
verses.text: Upon hearing this, the bishops exclaimed: "Nor again is this opposed to the doctrine of the Church".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:8
verses.text: For who indeed could condemn or deny the freedom of the will, when God's help is associated with it? His opinion, therefore, as thus explained in his answer, was, with good reason, deemed satisfactory by the bishops.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:9
verses.text: And yet, after all, the statement made in his book, "All men are ruled by their own will," ought without doubt to have deeply disturbed the brethren, who had discovered what these men are accustomed to dispute against the grace of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:10
verses.text: For it is said, "All men are ruled by their own will," as if God rules no man, and the Scripture says in vain, "Save Thy people, and bless Thine inheritance; rule them, and lift them up for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:11
verses.text: They would not, of course, stay, if they are ruled only by their own will without God, even as sheep which have no shepherd: which, God forbid for us.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:12
verses.text: For, unquestionably to be led is something more compulsory than to be ruled.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:13
verses.text: He who is ruled at the same time does something himself,—indeed, when ruled by God, it is with the express view that he should also act rightly; whereas the man who is led can hardly be understood to do any thing himself at all.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:14
verses.text: And yet the Saviour's helpful grace is so much better than our own wills and desires, that the apostle does not hesitate to say: "As many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 5:15
verses.text: And our free will can do nothing better for us than to submit itself to be led by Him who can do nothing amiss; and after doing this, not to doubt that it was helped to do it by Him of whom it is said in the psalm, "He is my God, His mercy shall go before me".

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 6

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 6:2
verses.text: —Pelagius' Answer Examined.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 6:3
verses.text: Indeed, in this very book which contains these statements, after laying down the position, "All men are governed by their own will, and every one is submitted to his own desire," Pelagius goes on to adduce the testimony of Scripture, from which it is evident enough that no man ought to trust to himself for direction.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 6:4
verses.text: For on this very subject the Wisdom of Solomon declares: "I myself also am a mortal man like unto all; and the offspring of him that was first made of the earth,"—with other similar words to the conclusion of the paragraph, where we read: "For all men have one entrance into life, and the like going out therefrom: wherefore I prayed and understanding was given to me; I called, and the Spirit of Wisdom came into me".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 6:5
verses.text: Now is it not clearer than light itself, how that this man, on duly considering the wretchedness of human frailty, did not dare to commit himself to his own direction, but prayed, and understanding was given to him, concerning which the apostle says: "But we have the understanding of the Lord;" and called, and the Spirit of Wisdom entered into him? Now it is by this Spirit, and not by the strength of their own will, that they who are God's children are governed and led.

verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:3
verses.text: As for the passage from the psalm, "He loved cursing, and it shall come upon him; and he willed not blessing, so it shall be far removed from him," which he quoted in the same book of Chapters, as if to prove that "all men are ruled by their own will," who can be ignorant that this is a fault not of nature as God created it, but of human will which departed from God? The fact indeed is, that even if he had not loved cursing, and had willed blessing, he would in this very case, too, deny that his will had received any assistance from God; in his ingratitude and impiety, moreover, he would submit himself to be ruled by himself, until he found out by his penalties that, sunk as he was into ruin, without God to govern him he was utterly unable to direct his own self.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:4
verses.text: In like manner, from the passage which he quoted in the same book under the same head, "He hath set fire and water before thee; stretch forth thy hand unto whether thou wilt; before man are good and evil, life and death, and whichever he liketh shall be given to him," it is manifest that, if he applies his hand to fire, and if evil and death please him, his human will effects all this; but if, on the contrary, he loves goodness and life, not alone does his will accomplish the happy choice, but it is assisted by divine grace.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:5
verses.text: The eye indeed is sufficient for itself, for not seeing, that is, for darkness; but for seeing, it is in its own light not sufficient for itself unless the assistance of a clear external light is rendered to it.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:6
verses.text: God forbid, however, that they who are "the called according to His purpose, whom He also foreknew, and predestinated to be conformed to the likeness of His Son," should be given up to their own desire to perish.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:7
verses.text: This is suffered only by "the vessels of wrath," who are perfected for perdition; in whose very destruction, indeed, God "makes known the riches of His glory on the vessels of His mercy".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:8
verses.text: Now it is on this account that, after saying, "He is my God, His mercy shall go before me," he immediately adds, "My God will show me vengeance upon my enemies".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:9
verses.text: That therefore happens to them which is mentioned in Scripture, "God gave them up to the lusts of their own heart".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:10
verses.text: This, however, does not happen to the predestinated, who are ruled by the Spirit of God, for not in vain is their cry: "Deliver me not, O Lord, to the sinner, according to my desire".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:11
verses.text: With regard, indeed, to the evil lusts which assail them, their prayer has ever assumed some such shape as this: "Take away from me the concupiscence of the belly; and let not the desire of lust take hold of me".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 7:12
verses.text: Upon those whom He governs as His subjects does God bestow this gift; but not upon those who think themselves capable of governing themselves, and who, in the stiff-necked confidence of their own will, disdain to have Him as their ruler.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:3
verses.text: This being the case, how must God's children, who have learned the truth of all this and rejoice at being ruled and led by the Spirit of God, have been affected when they heard or read that Pelagius had declared in writing that "all men are governed by their own will, and that every one is submitted to his own desire?" And yet, when questioned by the bishops, he fully perceived what an evil impression these words of his might produce, and told them in answer that "he had made such an assertion in the interest of free will,"—adding at once, "God is its helper whenever it chooses good; whilst man is himself in fault when he sins, as being under the influence of a free will".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:4
verses.text: Although the pious judges approved of this sentiment also, they were unwilling to consider or examine how incautiously he had written, or indeed in what sense he had employed the words found in his book.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:5
verses.text: They thought it was enough that he had made such a confession concerning free will, as to admit that God helped the man who chose the good, whereas the man who sinned was himself to blame, his own will sufficing for him in this direction.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:6
verses.text: According to this, God rules those whom He assists in their choice of the good.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 8:7
verses.text: So far, then, as they rule anything themselves, they rule it rightly, since they themselves are ruled by Him who is right and good.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:2
verses.text: —The Third Item in the Accusation; And Pelagius' Answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:3
verses.text: Another statement was read which Pelagius had placed in his book, to this effect: "In the day of judgment no forbearance will be shown to the ungodly and the sinners, but they will be consumed in eternal fires".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:4
verses.text: This induced the brethren to regard the statement as open to the objection, that it seemed so worded as to imply that all sinners whatever were to be punished with an eternal punishment, without excepting even those who hold Christ as their foundation, although "they build thereupon wood, hay, stubble," concerning whom the apostle writes: "If any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss; but he shall himself be saved, yet so as by fire".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:5
verses.text: When, however, Pelagius responded that "he had made his assertion in accordance with the Gospel, in which it is written concerning sinners, 'These shall go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into life eternal,'" it was impossible for Christian judges to be dissatisfied with a sentence which is written in the Gospel, and was spoken by the Lord; especially as they knew not what there was in the words taken from Pelagius' book which could so disturb the brethren, who were accustomed to hear his discussions and those of his followers.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:6
verses.text: Since also they were absent who presented the indictment against Pelagius to the holy bishop Eulogius, there was no one to urge him that he ought to distinguish, by some exception, between those sinners who are to be saved by fire, and those who are to be punished with everlasting perdition.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 9:7
verses.text: If, indeed, the judges had come to understand by these means the reason why the objection had been made to his statement, had he then refused to allow the distinction, he would have been justly open to blame.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:2
verses.text: —Pelagius' Answer Examined.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:3
verses.text: On Origen's Error Concerning the Non-Eternity of the Punishment of the Devil and the Damned.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:4
verses.text: But what Pelagius added, "Who believes differently is an Origenist," was approved by the judges, because in very deed the Church most justly abominates the opinion of Origen, that even they whom the Lord says are to be punished with everlasting punishment, and the devil himself and his angels, after a time, however protracted, will be purged, and released from their penalties, and shall then cleave to the saints who reign with God in the association of blessedness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:5
verses.text: This additional sentence, therefore, the synod pronounced to be "not opposed to the Church,"—not in accordance with Pelagius, but rather in accordance with the Gospel, that such ungodly and sinful men shall be consumed by eternal fires as the Gospel determines to be worthy of such a punishment; and that he is a sharer in Origen's abominable opinion, who affirms that their punishment can possibly ever come to an end, when the Lord has said it is to be eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:6
verses.text: Concerning those sinners, however, of whom the apostle declares that "they shall be saved, yet so as by fire, after their work has been burnt up," inasmuch as no objectionable opinion in reference to them was manifestly charged against Pelagius, the synod determined nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:7
verses.text: Wherefore he who says that the ungodly and sinner, whom the truth consigns to eternal punishment, can ever be liberated therefrom, is not unfitly designated by Pelagius as an "Origenist".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:8
verses.text: But, on the other hand, he who supposes that no sinner whatever deserves mercy in the judgment of God, may be designated by whatever name Pelagius is disposed to give to him, only it must at the same time be quite understood that this error is not received as truth by the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 10:9
verses.text: "For he shall have judgment without mercy that hath showed no mercy".

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:3
verses.text: But how this judgment is to be accomplished, it is not easy to understand from Holy Scripture; for there are many modes therein of describing that which is to come to pass only in one mode.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:4
verses.text: In one place the Lord declares that He will "shut the door" against those whom He does not admit into His kingdom; and that, on their clamorously demanding admission, "Open unto us,.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:5
verses.text: we have eaten and drunk in Thy presence," and so forth, as the Scripture describes, "He will say unto them in answer, I know you not,.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:6
verses.text: all ye workers of iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:7
verses.text: In another passage He reminds us that He will command "all which would not that He should reign over them to be brought to Him, and be slain in His presence".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:8
verses.text: In another place, again, He tells us that He will come with His angels in His majesty; and before Him shall be gathered all nations, and He shall separate them one from another; some He will set on His right hand, and after enumerating their good works, will award to them eternal life; and others on His left hand, whose barrenness in all good works He will expose, will He condemn to everlasting fire.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:9
verses.text: In two other passages He deals with that wicked and slothful servant, who neglected to trade with His money, and with the man who was found at the feast without the wedding garment,—and He orders them to be bound hand and foot, and to be cast into outer darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:10
verses.text: And in yet another scripture, after admitting the five virgins who were wise, He shuts the door against the other five foolish ones.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:11
verses.text: Now these descriptions,—and there are others which at the instant do not occur to me,—are all intended to represent to us the future judgment, which of course will be held not over one, or over five, but over multitudes.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:12
verses.text: For if it were a solitary case only of the man who was cast into outer darkness for not having on the wedding garment, He would not have gone on at once to give it a plural turn, by saying: "For many are called, but few are chosen;"  whereas it is plain that, after the one was cast out and condemned, many still remained behind in the house.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:13
verses.text: However, it would occupy us too long to discuss all these questions to the full.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:14
verses.text: This brief remark, however, I may make, without prejudice (as they say in pecuniary affairs) to some better discussion, that by the many descriptions which are scattered throughout the Holy Scriptures there is signified to us but one mode of final judgment, which is inscrutable to us,—with only the variety of deservings preserved in the rewards and punishments.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:15
verses.text: Touching the particular point, indeed, which we have before us at present, it is sufficient to remark that, if Pelagius had actually said that all sinners whatever without exception would be punished in an eternity of punishment by everlasting fire, then whosoever had approved of this judgment would, to begin with, have brought the sentence down on his own head.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 11:16
verses.text: "For who will boast that he is pure from sins?" Forasmuch, however, as he did not say all, nor certain, but made an indefinite statement only,—and afterwards, in explanation, declared that his meaning was according to the words of the Gospel,—his opinion was affirmed by the judgment of the bishops to be true; but it does not even now appear what Pelagius really thinks on the subject, and in consequence there is no indecency in inquiring further into the decision of the episcopal judges.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12 (IV.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:2
verses.text: )—The Fourth Item in the Accusation; And Pelagius' Answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:3
verses.text: It was further objected against Pelagius, as if he had written in his book, that "evil does not enter our thoughts".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:4
verses.text: In reply, however, to this charge, he said: "We made no such statement.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:5
verses.text: What we did say was, that the Christian ought to be careful not to have evil thoughts".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:6
verses.text: Of this, as it became them, the bishops approved.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:7
verses.text: For who can doubt that evil ought not to be thought of? And, indeed, if what he said in his book about "evil not being thought" runs in this form, "neither is evil to be thought of," the ordinary meaning of such words is "that evil ought not even to be thought of".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:8
verses.text: Now if any person denies this, what else does he in fact say, than that evil ought to be thought of? And if this were true, it could not be said in praise of love that "it thinketh no evil!" But after all, the phrase about "not entering into the thoughts" of righteous and holy men is not quite a commendable one, for this reason, that what enters the mind is commonly called a thought, even when assent to it does not follow.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:9
verses.text: The thought, however, which contracts blame, and is justly forbidden, is never unaccompanied with assent.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:10
verses.text: Possibly those men had an incorrect copy of Pelagius' writings, who thought it proper to object to him that he had used the words: "Evil does not enter into our thoughts;" that is, that whatever is evil never enters into the thoughts of righteous and holy men.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:11
verses.text: Which is, of course, a very absurd statement.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:12
verses.text: For whenever we censure evil things, we cannot enunciate them in words, unless they have been thought.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 12:13
verses.text: But, as we said before, that is termed a culpable thought of evil which carries with it assent.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13 (V.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:2
verses.text: )—The Fifth Item of the Accusation; And Pelagius' Answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:3
verses.text: After the judges had accorded their approbation to this answer of Pelagius, another passage which he had written in his book was read aloud: "The kingdom of heaven was promised even in the Old Testament".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:4
verses.text: Upon this, Pelagius remarked in vindication: "This can be proved by the Scriptures: but heretics, in order to disparage the Old Testament, deny this.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:5
verses.text: I, however, simply followed the authority of the Scriptures when I said this; for in the prophet Daniel it is written: 'The saints shall receive the kingdom of the Most.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:6
verses.text: High.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 13:7
verses.text: '" After they had heard this answer, the synod said: "Neither is this opposed to the Church's faith".

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:2
verses.text: —Examination of This Point.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:3
verses.text: The Phrase "Old Testament" Used in Two Senses.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:4
verses.text: The Heir of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:5
verses.text: In the Old Testament There Were Heirs of the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:6
verses.text: Was it therefore without reason that our brethren were moved by his words to include this charge among the others against him? Certainly not.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:7
verses.text: The fact is, that the phrase Old Testament is constantly employed in two different ways,—in one, following the authority of the Holy Scriptures; in the other, following the most common custom of speech.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:8
verses.text: For the Apostle Paul says, in his Epistle to the Galatians: "Tell me, ye that desire to be under the law, do ye not hear the law? For it is written that Abraham had two sons, the one by a bond-maid, the other by a free woman.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:9
verses.text: Which things are an allegory: for these are the two testaments; the one which gendereth to bondage, which is Agar.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:10
verses.text: For this is Mount Sinai in Arabia, and is conjoined with the Jerusalem which now is, and is in bondage with her children; whereas the Jerusalem which is above is free, and is the mother of us all".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:11
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as the Old Testament belongs to bondage, whence it is written, "Cast out the bond-woman and her son, for the son of the bond-woman shall not be heir with my son Isaac," but the kingdom of heaven to liberty; what has the kingdom of heaven to do with the Old Testament? Since, however, as I have already remarked, we are accustomed, in our ordinary use of words, to designate all those Scriptures of the law and the prophets which were given previous to the Lord's incarnation, and are embraced together by canonical authority, under the name and title of the Old Testament, what man who is ever so moderately informed in ecclesiastical lore can be ignorant that the kingdom of heaven could be quite as well promised in those early Scriptures as even the New Testament itself, to which the kingdom of heaven belongs? At all events, in those ancient Scriptures it is most distinctly written: "Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that I will consummate a new testament with the house of Israel and with the house of Jacob; not according to the testament that I made with their fathers, in the day that I took them by the hand, to lead them out of the land of Egypt".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:12
verses.text: This was done on Mount Sinai.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:13
verses.text: But then there had not yet risen the prophet Daniel to say: "The saints shall receive the kingdom of the Most High".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:14
verses.text: For by these words he foretold the merit not of the Old, but of the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:15
verses.text: In the same manner did the same prophets foretell that Christ Himself would come, in whose blood the New Testament was consecrated.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:16
verses.text: Of this Testament also the apostles became the ministers, as the most blessed Paul declares: "He hath made us able ministers of the New Testament; not in its letter, but in spirit: for the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:17
verses.text: In that testament, however, which is properly called the Old, and was given on Mount Sinai, only earthly happiness is expressly promised.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:18
verses.text: Accordingly that land, into which the nation, after being led through the wilderness, was conducted, is called the land of promise, wherein peace and royal power, and the gaining of victories over enemies, and an abundance of children and of fruits of the ground, and gifts of a similar kind are the promises of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:19
verses.text: And these, indeed, are figures of the spiritual blessings which appertain to the New Testament; but yet the man who lives under God's law with those earthly blessings for his sanction, is precisely the heir of the Old Testament, for just such rewards are promised and given to him, according to the terms of the Old Testament, as are the objects of his desire according to the condition of the old man.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:20
verses.text: But whatever blessings are there figuratively set forth as appertaining to the New Testament require the new man to give them effect.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:21
verses.text: And no doubt the great apostle understood perfectly well what he was saying, when he described the two testaments as capable of the allegorical distinction of the bond-woman and the free,—attributing the children of the flesh to the Old, and to the New the children of the promise: "They," says he, "which are the children of the flesh, are not the children of God; but the children of the promise are counted for the seed".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:22
verses.text: The children of the flesh, then, belong to the earthly Jerusalem, which is in bondage with her children; whereas the children of the promise belong to the Jerusalem above, the free, the mother of us all, eternal in the heavens.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:23
verses.text: Whence we can easily see who they are that appertain to the earthly, and who to the heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 14:24
verses.text: But then the happy persons, who even in that early age were by the grace of God taught to understand the distinction now set forth, were thereby made the children of promise, and were accounted in the secret purpose of God as heirs of the New Testament; although they continued with perfect fitness to administer the Old Testament to the ancient people of God, because it was divinely appropriated to that people in God's distribution of the times and seasons.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15:3
verses.text: How then should there not be a feeling of just disquietude entertained by the children of promise, children of the free Jerusalem, which is eternal in the heavens, when they see that by the words of Pelagius the distinction which has been drawn by Apostolic and catholic authority is abolished, and Agar is supposed to be by some means on a par with Sarah? He therefore does injury to the scripture of the Old Testament with heretical impiety, who with an impious and sacrilegious face denies that it was inspired by the good, supreme, and very God,—as Marcion does, as Manichaeus does, and other pests of similar opinions.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15:4
verses.text: On this account (that I may put into as brief a space as I can what my own views are on the subject), as much injury is done to the New Testament, when it is put on the same level with the Old Testament, as is inflicted on the Old itself when men deny it to be the work of the supreme God of goodness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15:5
verses.text: Now, when Pelagius in his answer gave as his reason for saying that even in the Old Testament there was a promise of the kingdom of heaven, the testimony of the prophet Daniel, who most plainly foretold that the saints should receive the kingdom of the Most High, it was fairly decided that the statement of Pelagius was not opposed to the catholic faith, although not according to the distinction which shows that the earthly promises of Mount Sinai are the proper characteristics of the Old Testament; nor indeed was the decision an improper one, considering that mode of speech which designates all the canonical Scriptures which were given to men before the Lord's coming in the flesh by the title of the "Old Testament".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 15:6
verses.text: The kingdom of the Most High is of course none other than the kingdom of God; otherwise, anybody might boldly contend that the kingdom of God is one thing, and the kingdom of heaven another.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16 (VI.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:2
verses.text: )—The Sixth Item of the Accusation, and Pelagius' Reply.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:3
verses.text: The next objection was to the effect that Pelagius in that same book of his wrote thus: "A man is able, if he likes, to be without sin;" and that writing to a certain widow he said, flatteringly: "In thee piety may find a dwelling-place, such as she finds nowhere else; in thee righteousness, though a stranger, can find a home; truth, which no one any longer recognises, can discover an abode and a friend in thee; and the law of God, which almost everybody despises, may be honoured by thee alone".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:4
verses.text: And in another sentence he writes to her: "O how happy and blessed art thou, when that righteousness which we must believe to flourish only in heaven has found a shelter on earth only in thy heart!" In another work addressed to her, after reciting the prayer of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, and teaching her in what manner saints ought to pray, he says: "He worthily raises his hands to God, and with a good conscience does he pour out his prayer, who is able to say, 'Thou, O Lord, knowest how holy, and harmless, and pure from all injury and iniquity and violence, are the hands which I stretch out to Thee; how righteous, and pure, and free from all deceit, are the lips with which I offer to Thee my supplication, that Thou wouldst have mercy upon me.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:5
verses.text: '" To all this Pelagius said in answer: "We asserted that a man could be without sin, and could keep God's commandments if he wished; for this capacity has been given to him by God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:6
verses.text: But we never said that any man could be found who at no time whatever, from infancy to old age, had committed sin: but that if any person were converted from his sins, he could by his own labour and God's grace be without sin; and yet not even thus would he be incapable of change ever afterwards.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:7
verses.text: As for the other statements which they have made against us, they are not to be found in our books, nor have we at any time said such things".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:8
verses.text: Upon hearing this vindication, the synod put this question to him: "You have denied having ever written such words; are you therefore ready to anathematize those who do hold these opinions?" Pelagius answered: "I anathematize them as fools, not as heretics, for there is no dogma".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 16:9
verses.text: The bishops then pronounced their judgment in these words: "Since now Pelagius has with his own mouth anathematized this vague statement as foolish verbiage, justly declaring in his reply, 'That a man is able with God's assistance and grace to be without sin,' let him now proceed to answer the other heads of accusation against him".

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 17

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 17:2
verses.text: —Examination of the Sixth Charge and Answers.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 17:3
verses.text: Well, now, had the judges either the power or the right to condemn these unrecognised and vague words, when no person on the other side was present to assert that Pelagius had written the very culpable sentences which were alleged to have been addressed by him to the widow? In such a matter, it surely could not be enough to produce a manuscript, and to read out of it words as his, if there were not also witnesses forthcoming in case he denied, on the words being read out, that they ever dropped from his pen.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 17:4
verses.text: But even here the judges did all that lay in their power to do, when they asked Pelagius whether he would anathematize the persons who held such sentiments as he declared he had never himself propounded either in speech or in writing.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 17:5
verses.text: And when he answered that he did anathematize them as fools, what right had the judges to push the inquiry any further on the matter, in the absence of Pelagius' opponents?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:3
verses.text: But perhaps the point requires some consideration, whether he was right in saying that "such as held the opinions in question deserved anathema, not as heretics, but as fools, since it was no dogma".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:4
verses.text: The question, when fairly confronted, is no doubt far from being an unimportant one,—how far a man deserves to be described as a heretic; on this occasion, however, the judges acted rightly in abstaining from it altogether.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:5
verses.text: If any one, for example, were to allege that eaglets are suspended in the talons of the parent bird, and so exposed to the rays of the sun, and such as wink are flung to the ground as spurious, the light being in some mysterious way the gauge of their genuine nature, he is not to be accounted a heretic, if the story happens to be untrue.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:6
verses.text: And, since it occurs in the writings of the learned and is very commonly received as fact, ought it to be considered a foolish thing to mention it, even though it be not true? much less ought our credit, which gains for us the name of being trustworthy, to be affected, on the one hand injuriously if the story be believed by us, or beneficially if disbelieved.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:7
verses.text: If, to go a step further in illustration, any one were from this opinion to contend that there existed in birds reasonable souls, from the notion that human souls at intervals passed into them, then indeed we should have to reject from our mind and ears alike an idea like this as the rankest heresy; and even if the story about the eagles were true (as there are many curious facts about bees before our eyes, that are true), we should still have to consider, and demonstrate, the great difference that exists between the condition of creatures like these, which are quite irrational, however surprising in their powers of sensation, and the nature which is common (not to men and beasts, but) to men and angels.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:8
verses.text: There are, to be sure, a great many foolish things said by foolish and ignorant persons, which yet fail to prove them heretics.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:9
verses.text: One might instance the silly talk so commonly heard about the pursuits of other people, from persons who have never learned these pursuits,—equally hasty and untenable whether in the shape of excessive and indiscriminate praise of those they love, or of blame in the case of those they happen to dislike.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:10
verses.text: The same remark might be made concerning the usual curent of human conversation: whenever it does touch on a subject which requires dogmatic acuracy of statement, but is thrown out at random or suggested by the passing moment, it is too often pervaded by foolish levity, whether uttered by the mouth or expressed in writing.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:11
verses.text: Many persons, indeed, when gently reminded of their reckless gossip, have afterwards much regretted their conduct; they scarcely recollected what they had never uttered with a fixed purpose, but had poured forth in a sheer volley of casual and unconsidered words.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:12
verses.text: It is, unhappily, almost impossible to be quite clear of such faults.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:13
verses.text: Who is he "that slippeth not in his tongue," and "offendeth not in word?" It, however, makes all the difference in the world, to what extent, and from what motive, and whether in fact at all, a man when warned of his fault corrects it, or obstinately clings to it so as to make a dogma and settled opinion of that which he had not at first uttered on purpose, but only in levity.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:14
verses.text: Although, then, it turns out eventually that every heretic is a fool, it does not follow that every fool must immediately be named a heretic.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:15
verses.text: The judges were quite right in saying that Pelagius had anathematized the vague folly under consideration by its fitting designation for even if it were heresy, there could be no doubt of its being foolish prattle.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:16
verses.text: Whatever, therefore, it was, they designated the offence under a general name.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 18:17
verses.text: But whether the quoted words had been used with any definitely dogmatic purpose, or only in a vague and indeterminate sense, and with an unmeaningness which should be capable of an easy correction, they did not deem it necessary to discuss on the present occasion, since the man who was on his trial before them denied that the words were his at all, in whatever sense they had been employed.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:3
verses.text: Now it so happened that, while we were reading this defence of Pelagius in the small paper which we received at first, there were present certain holy brethren, who said that they had in their possession some hortatory or consolatory works which Pelagius had addressed to a widow lady whose name did not appear, and they advised us to examine whether the words which he had abjured for his own occurred anywhere in these books.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:4
verses.text: They were not themselves aware whether they did or not.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:5
verses.text: The said books were accordingly read through, and the words in question were actually discovered in them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:6
verses.text: Moreover, they who had produced the copy of the book, affirmed that for now almost four years they had had these books as Pelagius', nor had they once heard a doubt expressed about his authorship.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:7
verses.text: Considering, then, from the integrity of these servants of God, which was very well known to us, how impossible it was for them to use deceit in the matter, the conclusion seemed inevitable, that Pelagius must be supposed by us to have rather been the deceiver at his trial before the bishops; unless we should think it possible that something may have been published, even for so many years, in his name, although not actually composed by him; for our informants did not tell us that they had received the books from Pelagius himself, nor had they ever heard him admit his own authorship.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:8
verses.text: Now, in my own case, certain of our brethren have told me that sundry writings have found their way into Spain under my name.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 19:9
verses.text: Such persons, indeed, as had read my genuine writings could not recognise those others as mine; although by other persons my authorship of them was quite believed.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 20.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:3
verses.text: Pelagius Acknowledges the Doctrine of Grace in Deceptive Terms.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:4
verses.text: There can be no doubt that what Pelagius has acknowledged as his own is as yet very obscure.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:5
verses.text: I suppose, however, that it will become apparent in the subsequent details of these proceedings.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:6
verses.text: Now he says: "We have affirmed that a man is able to be without sin, and to keep the commandments of God if he wishes, inasmuch as God has given him this ability.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:7
verses.text: But we have not said that any man can be found, who from infancy to old age has never committed sin; but that if any person were converted from his sins, he could by his own exertion and God's grace be without sin; and yet not even thus would he be incapable of change afterwards".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:8
verses.text: Now it is quite uncertain what he means in these words by the grace of God; and the judges, catholic as they were, could not possibly understand by the phrase anything else than the grace which is so very strongly recommended to us in the apostle's teaching.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:9
verses.text: Now this is the grace whereby we hope that we can be delivered from the body of this death through our Lord Jesus Christ, (VII.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:10
verses.text: ) and for the obtaining of which we pray that we may not be led into temptation.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:11
verses.text: This grace is not nature, but that which renders assistance to frail and corrupted nature.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:12
verses.text: This grace is not the knowledge of the law, but is that of which the apostle says: "I will not make void the grace of God: for if righteousness come by the law, then Christ is dead in vain".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:13
verses.text: Therefore it is not "the letter that killeth, but the life-giving spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:14
verses.text: For the knowledge of the law, without the grace of the Spirit, produces all kinds of concupiscence in man; for, as the apostle says, "I had not known sin but by the law: I had not known lust, unless the law had said, Thou shalt not covet.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:15
verses.text: But sin, taking occasion by the commandment, wrought in me all manner of concupiscence".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:16
verses.text: By saying this, however, he blames not the law; he rather praises it, for he says afterwards: "The law indeed is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:17
verses.text: And he goes on to ask: "Was then that which is good made death unto me? God forbid.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:18
verses.text: But sin, that it might appear sin, wrought death in me by that which is good".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:19
verses.text: And, again, he praises the law by saying: "We know that the law is spiritual; but I am carnal, sold under sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:20
verses.text: For that which I do I know not: for what I would, that do I not; but what I hate, that do I.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:21
verses.text: If then I do that which I would not, I consent unto the law that it is good".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:22
verses.text: Observe, then, he knows the law, praises it, and consents to it; for what it commands, that he also wishes; and what it forbids, and condemns, that he also hates: but for all that, what he hates, that he actually does.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:23
verses.text: There is in his mind, therefore, a knowledge of the holy law of God, but still his evil concupiscence is not cured.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:24
verses.text: He has a good will within him, but still what he does is evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 20:25
verses.text: Hence it comes to pass that, amidst the mutual struggles of the two laws within him,—"the law in his members warring against the law of his mind, and making him captive to the law of sin,"—he confesses his misery; and exclaims in such words as these: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from this body of death? The grace of God, through Jesus Christ our Lord".

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 21

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 21 (VIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 21:2
verses.text: )—The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 21:3
verses.text: It is not nature, therefore, which, sold as it is under sin and wounded by the offence, longs for a Redeemer and Saviour; nor is it the knowledge of the law—through which comes the discovery, not the expulsion, of sin—which delivers us from the body of this death; but it is the Lord's good grace through our Lord Jesus Christ.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 21 (IX.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:2
verses.text: )—The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:3
verses.text: This grace is not dying nature, nor the slaying letter, but the vivifying spirit; for already did he possess nature with freedom of will, because he said: "To will is present with me".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:4
verses.text: Nature, however, in a healthy condition and without a flaw, he did not possess, for he said: "I know that in me (that is, in my flesh) dwelleth nothing good".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:5
verses.text: Already had he the knowledge of God's holy law, for he said: "I had not known sin but through the law;" yet for all that, he did not possess strength and power to practise and fulfil righteousness, for he complained: "What I would, that do I not; but what I hate, that do I".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:6
verses.text: And again, "How to accomplish that which is good I find not".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 22:7
verses.text: Therefore it is not from the liberty of the human will, nor from the precepts of the law, that there comes deliverance from the body of this death; for both of these he had already,—the one in his nature, the other in his learning; but all he wanted was the help of the grace of God, through Jesus Christ our Lord.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 22 (X.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:2
verses.text: )—The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:3
verses.text: The Synod Supposed that the Grace Acknowledged by Pelagius Was that Which Was So Thoroughly Known to the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:4
verses.text: This grace, then, which was most completely known in the catholic Church (as the bishops were well aware), they supposed Pelagius made confession of, when they heard him say that "a man, when converted from his sins, is able by his own exertion and the grace of God to be without sin".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:5
verses.text: For my own part, however, I remembered the treatise which had been given to me, that I might refute it, by those servants of God, who had been Pelagius' followers.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:6
verses.text: They, notwithstanding their great affection for him, plainly acknowledged that the passage was his; when, on this question being proposed, because he had already given offence to very many persons from advancing views against the grace of God, he most expressly admitted that "what he meant by God's grace was that, when our nature was created, it received the capacity of not sinning, because it was created with free will".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:7
verses.text: On account, therefore, of this treatise, I cannot help feeling still anxious, whilst many of the brethren who are well acquainted with his discussions, share in my anxiety, lest under the ambiguity which notoriously characterizes his words there lies some latent reserve, and lest he should afterwards tell his followers that it was without prejudice to his own doctrine that he made any admissions,—discoursing thus: "I no doubt asserted that a man was able by his own exertion and the grace of God to live without sin; but you know very well what I mean by grace; and you may recollect reading that grace is that in which we are created by God with a free will".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:8
verses.text: Accordingly, while the bishops understood him to mean the grace by which we have by adoption been made new creatures, not that by which we were created (for most plainly does Holy Scripture instruct us in the former sense of grace as the true one), ignorant of his being a heretic, they acquitted him as a catholic.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:9
verses.text: I must say that my suspicion is excited also by this, that in the work which I answered, he most openly said that "righteous Abel never sinned at all".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:10
verses.text: Now, however, he thus expresses himself: "But we did not say that any man could be found who at no time whatever, from infancy to old age, has committed sin; but that, if any man were converted from his sins, he could by his own labour and God's grace be without sin".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:11
verses.text: When speaking of righteous Abel, he did not say that after being converted from his sins he became sinless in a new life, but that he never committed sin at all.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:12
verses.text: If, then, that book be his, it must of course be corrected and amended from his answer.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:13
verses.text: For I should be sorry to say that he was insincere in his more recent statement; lest perhaps he should say that he had forgotten what he had previously written in the book we have quoted.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:14
verses.text: Let us therefore direct our view to what afterwards occurred.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 23:15
verses.text: Now, from the sequel of these ecclesiastical proceedings, we can by God's help show that, although Pelagius, as some suppose, cleared himself in his examination, and was at all events acquitted by his judges (who were, however, but human beings after all), that this great heresy, which we should be most unwilling to see making further progress or becoming aggravated in guilt, was undoubtedly itself condemned.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 23 (XI.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:2
verses.text: )—The Seventh Item of the Accusation: the Breviates of Coelestius Objected to Pelagius.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:3
verses.text: Then follow sundry statements charged against Pelagius, which are said to be found among the opinions of his disciple Coelestius: how that "Adam was created mortal, and would have died whether he had sinned or not sinned; that Adam's sin injured only himself and not the human race; that the law no less than the gospel leads us to the kingdom; that there were sinless men previous to the coming of Christ; that new-born infants are in the same condition as Adam was before the fall; that the whole human race does not, on the one hand, die through Adam's death or transgression, nor, on the other hand, does the whole human race rise again through the resurrection of Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:4
verses.text: These have been so objected to, that they are even said to have been, after a full hearing, condemned at Carthage by your holiness and other bishops associated with you.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:5
verses.text: I was not present on that occasion, as you will recollect; but afterwards, on my arrival at Carthage, I read over the Acts of the synod, some of which I perfectly well remember, but I do not know whether all the tenets now mentioned occur among them.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:6
verses.text: But what matters it if some of them were possibly not mentioned, and so not included in the condemnation of the synod when it is quite clear that they deserve condemnation? Sundry other points of error were next alleged against him, connected with the mention of my own name.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:7
verses.text: They had been transmitted to me from Sicily, some of our Catholic brethren there being perplexed by questions of this kind; and I drew up a reply to them in a little work addressed to Hilary, who had consulted me respecting them in a letter.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:8
verses.text: My answer, in my opinion, was a sufficient one.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:9
verses.text: These are the errors referred to: "That a man is able to be without sin if he wishes.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:10
verses.text: That infants, even if they die unbaptized, have eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 24:11
verses.text: That rich men, even if they are baptized, unless they renounce all, have, whatever good they may seem to have done, nothing of it reckoned to them; neither can they possess the kingdom of God".

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 24.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:2
verses.text: —Pelagius' Answer to the Charges Brought Together Under the Seventh Item.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:3
verses.text: The following, as the proceedings testify, was Pelagius' own answer to these charges against him: "Concerning a man's being able indeed to be without sin, we have spoken," says he, "already; concerning the fact, however, that before the Lord's coming there were persons without sin, we say now that, previous to Christ's advent, some men lived holy and righteous lives, according to the teaching of the sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:4
verses.text: The rest were not said by me, as even their testimony goes to show, and for them, I do not feel that I am responsible.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:5
verses.text: But for the satisfaction of the holy synod, I anathematize those who either now hold, or have ever held, these opinions".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:6
verses.text: After hearing this answer of his, the synod said: "With regard to these charges aforesaid, Pelagius has in our presence given us sufficient and proper satisfaction, by anathematizing the opinions which were not his".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 25:7
verses.text: We see, therefore, and maintain that the most pernicious evils of this heresy have been condemned, not only by Pelagius, but also by the holy bishops who presided over that inquiry:—that "Adam was made mortal;" (and, that the meaning of this statement might be more clearly understood, it was added, "and he would have died whether he had sinned or not sinned;") that his sin injured only himself and not the human race; that the law, no less than the gospel, leads us to the kingdom of heaven; that new born infants are in the same condition that Adam was before the fall; that the entire human race does not, on the one hand, die through Adam's death and transgression, nor, on the other hand, does the whole human race rise again through the resurrection of Christ; that infants, even if they die unbaptized, have eternal life; that rich men even if baptized, unless they renounce and give up all, have, whatever good they may seem to have done, nothing of it reckoned to them, neither can they possess the kingdom of God;"—all these opinions, at any rate, were clearly condemned in that ecclesiastical court,—Pelagius pronouncing the anathema, and the bishops the interlocutory sentence.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 25.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:2
verses.text: —The Pelagians Falsely Pretended that the Eastern Churches Were on Their Side.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:3
verses.text: Now, by reason of these questions, and the very contentious assertions of these tenets, which are everywhere accompanied with heated feelings, many weak brethren were disturbed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:4
verses.text: We have accordingly, in the anxiety of that love which it becomes us to feel towards the Church of Christ through His grace, and out of regard to Marcellinus of blessed memory (who was extremely vexed day by day by these disputers, and who asked my advice by letter), been obliged to write on some of these questions, and especially on the baptism of infants.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:5
verses.text: On this same subject also I afterwards, at your request, and assisted by your prayers, delivered an earnest address, to the best of my ability, in the church of the Majores, holding in my hands an epistle of the most glorious martyr Cyprian, and reading therefrom and applying his words on the very matter, in order to remove this dangerous error out of the hearts of sundry persons, who had been persuaded to take up with the opinions which, as we see, were condemned in these proceedings.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:6
verses.text: These opinions it has been attempted by their promoters to force upon the minds of some of the brethren, by threatening, as if from the Eastern Churches, that unless they adopted the said opinions, they would be formally condemned by those Churches.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:7
verses.text: Observe, however, that no less than fourteen bishops of the Eastern Church, assembled in synod in the land where the Lord manifested His presence in the days of His flesh, refused to acquit Pelagius unless he condemned these opinions as opposed to the Catholic faith.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:8
verses.text: Since, therefore, he was then acquitted because he anathematized such views, it follows beyond a doubt that the said opinions were condemned.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 26:9
verses.text: This, indeed, will appear more clearly still, and on still stronger evidence, in the sequel.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 27

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 26.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Proceedings of Pelagius 27:2
